item.title: GTA 6 couldn't be made by AI suggests Take-Two boss: "There is no creativity that can exist by definition in any AI model"
item.content:encoded:
"You wouldn't end up with anything very good."

Take-Two Interactive boss Strauss Zelnick has returned to the subject of AI, this time suggesting the controversial technology could never create anything like GTA 6 because "no creativity... can exist by definition in any AI model."

Zelnick has taken a measured position on artificial intelligence - a term he's previously described as an "oxymoron" - in the past, saying that while he's "pretty enthusiastic" about its potential to help the company "do a better job and to do a more efficient job" as a tool, it takes "genius" to "create hits" and "genius is the domain of human beings".

His latest comments, shared during CNBC's recent Technology Executive Council Summit, expand on that perspective, specifically in regard to AI's "derivative" nature. One immediate concern for Strauss is copyright. "We have to protect our intellectual property, but more than that, we have to be mindful of others," he explained. "If you create intellectual property with AI, it's not protectable." Ultimately, Take-Two's content must stand up to copyright laws, he added, while also protecting people's rights, leading to "constraints".

But Zelnick also believes the inherently "backward looking" nature of AI - a result of its dependence on big data sets of old information - means it's "derivative" in a way that doesn't suit creativity. "Let's say there were no constraints [on AI]. Could we push a button tomorrow and create an equivalent to the Grand Theft Auto marketing plan?" he continued. "The answer is no. A, you can't do that yet, and B, I am of the view that you wouldn't end up with anything very good. You end up with something pretty derivative."

"There are many, many, many things in life that are predictable based on data," he added. "Anything that involves backward-looking data compute, [AI is] really good for that and that applies to lots of things [but] what we do at Take-Two, anything that isn't attached to that, it's going to be really, really bad at."

Referencing Grand Theft Auto specifically, Zelnick added, "What [developer] Rockstar Games tries to do, and so far has done over and over again, is create something that approaches perfection... There is no creativity that can exist by definition in any AI model, because it is data-driven."

GTA 6 launches on 26th May 2026 following its delay earlier this year.



https://www.eurogamer.net/gta-6-couldnt-be-made-by-ai-suggests-take-two-boss-there-is-no-creativity-that-can-exist-by-definition-in-any-ai-model

item.title: Trump administration's use of Halo "ought to offend every Halo fan, regardless of political orientation", says key series designer
item.content:encoded:
"I personally find it despicable."

The backlash to the Trump administration's use of AI Halo imagery to promote political causes - notably the use of force by ICE to detain purportedly illegal immigrants - has spread to include strongly worded responses from the original designers of the Halo game.

Jaime Griesemer, who worked as a designer at Bungie for 12 years, on all Halo games up to Halo: Reach, told Game File that: "Using Halo imagery in a call to 'destroy' people because of their immigration status goes way too far, and ought to offend every Halo fan, regardless of political orientation. I personally find it despicable. The Flood are evil space zombie parasites and are not an allegory to any group of people."

His comments refer to an image posted by the Department of Homeland Security which showed two Spartan soldiers on a Warthog jeep, riding across a Halo ring world, underneath the words "Destroy the Flood" and a call to join ICE. The inference was clear.

Marcus Lehto, the co-creator of Halo and lead designer of Master Chief, added to Game File that: "It really makes me sick seeing Halo co-opted like this." The DHS Flood-related image in particular was "absolutely abhorrent", he said.

Incidentally, Lehto and Griesemer featured in a news story earlier this week responding to the Halo 1 campaign remake, voicing confusion at some of the apparent design decisions in it. And it's this Halo remake which sparked the flurry of Halo-related AI images used by the Trump administration.

So far Microsoft - owner of the Halo IP - hasn't noticeably said or done anything about the Trump administration's use of Master Chief and Halo. The ongoing silence speaks volumes. It follows similar inaction by Nintendo when the Trump administration co-opted Pokémon for similar social media use. Thus emboldened, the Trump administration's provocative use of iconic IP continues, now reaching The Lord of the Rings.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/trump-administrations-use-of-halo-ought-to-offend-every-halo-fan-regardless-of-political-orientation-says-key-series-designer

item.title: Arc Raiders Online connection errors are causing havoc, as 130,000+ players flood the servers minutes after launch
item.content:encoded:
Arc Raiders servers have gone live, and following the historical trend of massive releases and server woes, players are running into an Online Connection Error as thousands across PC and consoles flood in.

After booting up the game and attempting to connect to servers, a significant number of players have run into an error pop up that reads: "Online Connection Error. Online services are currently unavailable." Other players have managed to squeeze through, leading some players stubbornly spamming the bright yellow retry button in hopes of gaining access.

In the hours prior to the game's release on Steam, it shot up to the global number one ranking for Top Sellers on Steam. Within five minutes, over 100,000 concurrent players were in-game, an absurd number considering it's a work day today lads.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

As of writing there's been no public statement on official Arc Raiders channels on this error, so if you've booked a day off or are thriving in a remote role, you might not be having as smooth an Arc Raiders experience as you'd hoped. Still, shaky server problems like this are part of the charm. Just ask anyone who was awake for World of Warcraft: Warlords of Draenor's launch.

If you're curious about Arc Raiders, why not read Eurogamer's preview of the game for a relatively succinct jist of what the game's about!

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/arc-raiders-online-connection-error-launch-server-problem

item.title: What comes after the Xbox Series consoles? Well, it's pretty much just a PC - even the Microsoft CEO has said so
item.content:encoded:
PC, or not PC. That is the question.

Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has provided yet another hint that the next Xbox console will, in essence, be a PC, in a recent interview.

Speaking to TBPN, Nadella spoke at length about the companies' future plans when it comes to gaming, including the mysterious new console that Microsoft is working on. This includes direct mention of Steam as a competitor platform, and Microsoft's current significance as a video game publisher.

"To us, gaming on Windows… and of course, Steam has built a massive marketplace on top of it, and they’ve done a very successful job," Nadella states. "Now, we’re the largest publisher after the Activision [deal]. Therefore, we want to be a fantastic publisher. Similar approach to what we did with [Microsoft] Office. We want to be everywhere, in every platform.

"So we want to make sure, whether it’s consoles, whether it’s the PC, whether it’s mobile, whether it’s cloud gaming, or the TV, we just want to make sure the games are being enjoyed by gamers everywhere."

Nadella then moved on to future hardware, telling TBPN: "Second, we also wanted to do innovative work in the system side on the console and on the PC. It’s kind of funny that people think about the console-PC as two different things. We built the console because we wanted to build a better PC which could then perform for gaming. I kind of want to revisit some of that conventional wisdom."

This interview comes shortly after rumours ran amok that Xbox would not be creating another console after the Xbox Series, which was debunked by Xbox president Sarah Bond. She's also spoken at length about the "premium" nature of the upcoming Xbox, stating it'll be a "curated" experience, much like the ROG Xbox Ally.

The ROG Xbox Ally that has been met with mixed reception. Eurogamer editorial director Tom Orry described it as: "an impressive handheld PC wearing an Xbox mask", while editor-at-large Alex Donaldson came away from their time with the console longing for Xbox's past heyday. Others have found the presence of Microsoft apps like One Drive a hurdle to the gaming experience they could find on a Steam Deck.

Is this the future of an ‘Xbox PC’, a product loaded up with One Drive, Co-Pilot, and other non-gamer focused apps? It remains to be seen.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/what-comes-after-the-xbox-series-consoles-well-its-pretty-much-just-a-pc-even-the-microsoft-ceo-has-said-so
